content.description:
A nice little sport lead, with many bolts to keep your mental in check. Good mental/physical warm-up climb. 
  
 This is the route completely to the right of House Wall. It starts off with some big juggy holds that take you slightly to the right, and then 5.8-style small holds that bring you a bit to the left and up to the anchor. You might sometimes have to think about where you wanna put those feet!

Right-most set of bolts on House Wall.
7 bolts

There is a crack on House Wall, and Derek was the first to climb it. 
  
 Should you wish to follow in his footsteps, you may want to bring a trad rack with you.  
  
 The rock can be a little scary and placements not always straightforward as some aspects flare out (you may want to try out some of those off-set DMM nuts, they work wonders!)

Crack in the middle of House Wall
Rack to 1". You can probably fit some pink tricams in there. But pink Tricams fit anywhere. Pink Tricams are great. I love Pink Tricams. I'm not sponsered by C.A.M.P.

This route is basically a 5.8 except for one move over the bulge. Perhaps that's where it gets its name from. 
  
 Start just to the right of Untitled 2. Make your way towards the hold-less bulch higher to the right. Thankfully you will be clipped in when you make the move, although a fall is unlikely to be pleasant. Once over the bulge, breeze up veering slight right until you make it to the anchor. 
  
 There are many ways over the bulge. Some talk of finger holes, others of tiny crimps here and there. Others just pull on the rope to get over it.

6 Bolts! Anchor with rings at the top.

This is a great route! In my opinion the best that House Wall has to offer. 
  
 The route angles slowly to the left, going over two "cruxy" bulges. Each bulge offers itself with increasing intensity. The second bulge, right below the anchor, looks bare, but to the well-trained eye, or the "long-armed" climber, there are ways past these difficulties. 
  
 The route is a bolt-festival.

First set of bolts to the left on House Wall, start near the picnic table (if it hasn't moved).
7 bolts, anchor with rings at top.

There is nothing noteworthy about this route, other than the fact that it is a good route to practice leading trad on given the plethora of opportunities for placement. The route is the left-most one on House Wall, and shares an anchor with Hammerthumb to the right.

All you got! There is an anchor and rings at the top.

Make your merry way to the first bolt and pretend like it's nothing. You'll want to go around the bulge/column, find feet where you can, and holding onto whatever you find. Surprisingly crimpy in the middle section.  
  
 Once you are past the bulgy/column, take a hard left and go clip into the bolt while standing on a small ledge.  
  
 From there, go up. Be warned, there is a run-out from the last bolt to the anchor, but nothing too scary.

This route is the set of bolts immediately to the right of Derek's Crack.
5 Bolts to the top

This route is smack in the middle of Untitled 1 and False Expectations. Basically you go up in a straight line to the anchor on False Expectations.

Top Rope. Use anchor at top of False Expectations.

This is the chunk'o'rock which you saw from the highway and which got you all excited. Most people climb in this area which gets sun for a good part of the day - it is east-south-east facing! The rock is basalt, and in some places you'll want to test holds before you commit to them... 
  
 It's a great area to chill and do some short climbs on. There is a picnic table right next to a bunch of rocks arranged in a form that remotely resembles the beginnings (or end) of a house, hence the name. 
  
 There are top-rope, sport and trad routes here. Once you get to the top, it is possible to move around and rap-down on a different anchor (you should know what you are doing if you do this!) 
  
 HINT: Click on "Print a mini-guide on the right to print out a guide-book format of this area! Or you can also download the Mountain Project App for iPhone/iPad and view these pages when you are offline!"
